title: What “one-hit wonder” band isn’t really a one-hit wonder? - Quora

response.answer_text: These fellas.  “Oh yeah, the Take on Me guys with that one video, right?” I reckon it’s somewhat understandable for us stiff-necked Americans to hastily and permanently file them away under the category of “one-hit-wonder” (as made so clear in a recent Rolling Stone Magazine poll[1]) due to there being just two charting singles off of the first album (plus one very memorable music video to catch our attention), but when a band has in excess of 100 million albums sold worldwide[2] with less than 10% of that figure actually being from the album that spawned “Take On Me”, one could not be farther from the truth to call them a “one-hit-wonder”. If anything, hardworking guitarist/producer Paul Waaktaar-Savoy’s development of the A-ha sound into sophisticated pop music with surprisingly thoughtful lyrics over the past 35+ years has sure paid off, as 45 singles[3] off of ten studio albums[4] released with a wide-reaching audience around the globe has cumulatively made them so much bigger than when they first hit it in America. There are no less than a dozen A-ha tracks that will come to mind if you ask some folks about A-ha in many parts of the globe, and some of their biggest hits actually were released in the past decade and a half. . . . EDIT 2019/8/27 : Reading through the sheer diversity of posted comments on this answer for a second… If anything, I have a hunch that many people’s rather polarized opinions about the multi-hit success of A-ha (or lack thereof) pretty much quantifies what the original question was asking, and everyone’s input has been greatly appreciated :)  Footnotes[1] Poll: Top 10 One-Hit Wonders[2] a-ha - Music Norway EN[3] a-ha singles | a-ha live[4] A-ha discography - Wikipedia

I consistently end up shaking my head when I read articles about “one-hit wonders.” Inevitably, these lists include acts that have definitely had more than one hit. To be fair, there may not be agreement on what is considered a “hit.” If we are talking about the U.S., however, I would consider the Billboard Hot 100 chart to be the measure of whether or not a song was a “hit.” In the strictest of definitions, I would say any act with more than one Hot 100 entry could not be considered a one-hit wonder. However, some might argue that a “hit” needs to have at least charted in the top 40. Or top 20. Or top 10. As you can see, this certainly muddies the discussion. However, some of the most laughable claims I’ve seen in various articles include Sugarloaf (who had top 10 hits with “Green-Eyed Lady” AND “Don’t Call Us, We’ll Call You”), The Knack (“My Sharona” #1, “Good Girls Don’t” #11), and Aha (#1 hit with “Take on Me” and a top 20 hit with “The Sun Always Shines on TV”). Even more ludicrous are claims that Survivor was a one-hit wonder (“Eye of the Tiger” #1, “Burning Heart” #2, three more top tens with “High on You,” “The Search Is Over,” and “Is This Love”). There’s also Toto (“Africa” #1, “Rosanna” #2, top ten hits with “Hold the Line” and “I Won’t Hold You Back”). On the flip side, the article “The Complete List of True One-Hit Wonders” does a great job highlighting more than 50 acts who have only had one top 40 hit.
